segments.text: when non-black students were integrated into an all-white school after the 1954 Supreme Court ruling that separate was not equal and we should integrate with all deliberate speed, right?
That's right.
Okay.
Well, do you want to start by telling us something about your background, about your education and your term as mayor and a little bit about the background of the Little Rock crisis?
Born and raised in Little Rock.
Went to public schools there.
Graduated Little Rock Central High School in 1934.
Went to University of Illinois.
Graduated in 38 and worked in Chicago.
Served as a naval officer in World War II and came back to Little Rock in December 1945.
Became active in politics.
Were you active in politics before you were mayor?
Oh, yes.
What kind of things did you do?
Active in the Democratic Party, supporting and raising money for people seeking office on all levels, and then decided in 1955 to run for mayor of Little Rock.
had planned to, within two to four years, run for governor of the state.
That was my plan.
Could you tell us a little bit about the background between the court case and when Faubus called in the guard?
Well, when the Supreme Court ruled in 1954 that the
doctrine had been in effect for oh well and accessible hundred years that equal but separate facilities for whites and blacks was the way to run the educational system.
Their decision changed it and said that the facilities for blacks were not equal to and

in effect said that since the states are not willing nationwide to provide the money for blacks, that they were being deprived of their constitutional right for equal facilities for education, and that there should be a gradual integration of students regardless of color.
And it was a very controversial decision in all parts of the country, not just the South.
But since it was rooting of the Supreme Court, the states then and the individual school districts across the country began to put together gradual integration plans.
At that particular time, a friend of mine named Bert Blossom was the superintendent of schools in Pulaski County.

Even though he did not agree with the Supreme Court ruling, he accepted it as a so-called law of the land and put together a gradual plan that by meetings throughout the community, radio and television, over a period of a couple of years, the public knew about it.
And there appeared to be no reason to believe that the plan which was adopted by the school board unanimously would meet any objection in the community or the city.
Is this the way you felt?
Any violence.
That's what the school board felt.
The school board voted unanimously after carrying it to the community.
and even the newspapers agreed that the plan would be acceptable.
Governor Faubus, who was already a controversial figure and was completing his first term as governor, had already agreed, or his second term as governor,
has already agreed to step down and not seek re-election.
And he decided with half a dozen or so friends that they would oppose the school board's decision or plan.
He did this in such a dramatic fashion that he went on television on Sunday night before schools were to be integrated the following day in September of 1957.
And he said that there was rioting, that people across the country, across Arkansas and the whole state, the whole country would be coming in.
There would be rioting on the streets and that people would be killed and slaughtered and so forth and so on.
You say that perpetrated fraud upon the people of Little Rock particularly and the country as a whole because

claim to those of us in the state involved with what was happening, that he was using this to perpetuate himself in offices as long as he wanted to be governor of the state of Marksville, which happened.
He called in 2,000 National Guardmen, and they surrounded the school.
Were these half a dozen friends, were they political figures also or just personal friends of his?
No, we met on what he announced on Sunday evening.
And we called a meeting that night.
And the governor of the state, no, the ex-governor of the state,
Sid McMahon, the Lieutenant Governor of the state, I can't remember his name, one of the Senators, Congressman Brooks Hayes, Virgil Blossom, and most of the school board were present.
And we
were there to make some kind of decision how to meet the crisis that was certain to arise because the school was already surrounded.
Because he came on television and said the school was surrounded just when it was.
They were surrounded.
Didn't he warn that blood would run in the streets of Little Rock if the blacks tried to enter the school?
Yes.
How did the crowd react to the guards being around the school?
I mean, the guards themselves wouldn't let the kids through.

And I read that one girl, Elizabeth Eckford, I believe is her name, came up and thought that the guards would protect her because she didn't realize what had been said in the student superintendent meeting.
And she had tried to go through to the school anyway and felt that even the guards were giving her hate stares.
Do you think that the guards had?
They were there to keep them out.
The guard was there to keep them out of school.
But do you think that the guards had their, I mean, in their own opinion, were the guards against the National Guard?
It's hard to say.
It's hard to determine if the 2,000 were for or against it, but they had no choice.
They were members of the National Guard, and they were called out by the government of the state.
They had to be there.
But they were instructed not to let them in school, not to escort them in.
The only way in the world, this was a decision that was made that night, that the only way in the world they were going to get in was that, and this was done with Washington, D.C.'s approval.
We were dealing directly with, at that point, Richard Nixon, who was vice president.
Attorney General.
I can't remember his first name.
His last name was Rogers.
I can't remember his first name.
But it was determined that they would provide U.S.
Marshals to assist those nine students.
Did you call the President and ask him for support?
Well, it was a spontaneous situation.
The decision was made that night that we had to take immediate action and do something.
Otherwise, we would have an awful lot of trouble.
How long after the nine children tried to enter the school against the National Guard did it take before the troops came down and they actually got to go inside?
I think a week or so.
I'm not real sure.
I'm not real sure.
It didn't go on very long because nothing could happen.
One of the things we would say, we called out
Well, there were about 350 policemen at that particular time, about 350 firemen.
And part of the plan agreed on was that we would call, use approximately 75% of the police force and the firemen, the police force with no guns, only with their, what do you call those?
Not what you call the clubs or so forth and so on.
They weren't called that.
And the firemen only with fire hoses.
And... Is that to ward off the mob?
Yes, to prevent any mob violence and so forth and so on.
But definitely no shooting because that would defeat what we're trying to do and that is to preserve peace and order and no violence and people being killed or injured.
And...
The strange thing about the whole situation was that when I, as mayor, ordered this to be done, the chief of police and the chief of the fire department both resigned.
They would not do it.
Because they didn't believe in the desegregation.
Didn't believe in it.
And we had to bring in assistance.
How do you feel that this integration or the desegregation of Central High School could have taken place without the guard?
Do you think it would have gone over smoothly?
No problem.
You don't think there would have been any problem?
Whatever.
The responsibility of the individual school districts was spelled out.
the governor of the state and the federal government had no business at all interfering.
It was not their responsibility.
It was the responsibility of the board members and they'd already arrived at a plan.
It had taken two years to make certain that the public agreed with and was familiar with the plan and that it would come off according to the way it had been explained many, many, many times.
And had this action not been taken by the governor, there's no doubt in question at that time and now that it would have gone, you know, maybe some minor, but nothing unusual.
Did you hear any rumors or anything of any violence that would have happened?
Like, I mean, I know Fava's blew it way out of proportion that you didn't hear of hardly any.
So, um...
Oh, he had brought in 15 or 20 people with a reputation of being rabble-rousers, we call them, to excite and incite rioting.
As a matter of fact, the FBI knew that.
And that was our job, to make certain that...

bob did get excited and of course when it came on television the next morning there were triple thousand people out there just you know just going crazy you know going crazy i know there's so many people out there against the desegregation but were there a lot of people in the community that were for it that believed in it or were they most most of the most of the black people were obviously uh
And a small percentage of the white people.
You couldn't tell what percent.
A lot of them didn't want to say anything because... A lot of people didn't care.
Didn't bother.
Didn't make a difference.
What role do you feel that the media played in the... Did you think it was good or bad?
I know that it showed the whole world.
Grossly over-exaggerated.
Oh, really?
Locally, statewide, worldwide.
You think it helped any?
Grossly.
All it did was...

bring the situation to the attention of people that should have never been concerned about it, people that lived in other parts of the country, people who got involved that should have given it a second thought.
It was a local matter.
Just grossly over-exaggerated.
The morning after it happened,
after they integrated the school?
After that particular day in September, the morning after it happened, there must have been 150 newsmen from all over the world in the mayor's office with television cameras.
That's when I first met John Chancellor.
Oh, really?
I met him that day, and he was just a young man getting started.
But they had him all over the world.
They just wanted a scoop.
They wanted some juicy gossip.
That was it.
That was the biggest news item worldwide.
You were saying earlier that people just weren't accustomed to having blacks have any kind of freedom about eating lunch at any counters.
No, no.
Up until that point, the black people...
all over the country, particularly the South.
They didn't eat in restaurants.
They didn't go to picture shows and sit in balconies.
Public transportation, they sat in the back, including railroads, airplanes.
And they were discriminated against.
Had any of this started changing yet by the time that this little rock?
Really not.
I know one of the things that when I went in office as mayor in January of 56, for 150 years, the fountain, public fountains, water fountains, they were separate for black and for white.
Restrooms were black and white, you know.
We changed them all.
During your...
Within the first week.
Oh.
Within the first week, we changed.

This was something that was done because I felt they were citizens of the city and that they paid taxes like anybody else and that there was no reason why when they walked in the city hall for any reason that they should have to go to a separate restroom or go to a... break water out of a separate... And there was nothing said about it.
ignore press it was a lot of people felt differently that they should be different that they were different people
How did you come to be so open-minded?
Was it from your parents' views or from school or just your own personal disposition?
No, I had grown up in a family of modest men.
My father was in the commercialized business all of his adult life.
He hired and worked with 15 to 25 people, and they were both black and white.
And I didn't have any particular feelings about either way.
I didn't realize in growing up what it meant to be discriminated against at that particular time.
That's a neat view to see because you hardly ever hear about anyone who was open-minded about race relations at all during that time.
Well, I went to school at the University of Illinois at North.
I went to elementary and high school in Arkansas.
There were no blacks in school.
I went up there in almost every class.
Uh, we would have a few black students involved with me.
You know, some a reason why it should.
They were just as radiant or more so than most of the white kids in college.
They really didn't bother me.
And I'd worked in Chicago and Illinois for four years before I went in service.
Same thing, I worked with blacks.
They mostly were white.
I was a naval officer in World War II.
And the same thing, we had black officers on the Admiral Dempsey's staff, which I served on for 18 or 19 months.
And it didn't bother me.
It really didn't bother me.
Did it seem to bother other people that were on the staff with you?
No.
They were accepted, you know.
How was Horace Mann High School?
Was it in the books?
Just as good or better than Little Rock High School.
Just as good or better.
A lot of the arguments seem to be that they had such a good high school, why did they want to come to the white high school that had more people and was older, not well-equipped?
Was it separate but equal?
It was equal.
In what ways?
Equal facilities.
Probably...
90% of the black students going to Horseman High School did not want to go because they realized that they were not wanted there.
They realized that.
The nine students that started it?
Well, 90% of the students at Horseman High School and other high schools realized they were not wanted.
And they're no different than anybody else.
You don't associate people that you don't particularly feel comfortable with.
And they were the same way, exactly.
But the National Association, what do they call it now?
The NAACP was in its infancy at that particular time.
And there was a nationwide movement, one of which was Martin Luther King.
There was a nationwide movement to do something about civil rights, and education was where they wanted to start, which I did not agree with.
I don't agree with today that you shouldn't take children
and use them to advance the cause of the people as a rule.
They should have taken grown people if they wanted to bring about equal civil rights and not use children, young children, six, eight, 10, 12, up through high school age,
And I still remember that night when the NAACP was organized to do this very thing.
And this Daisy Bates that you referred to a while ago, she was the leader.
of the local community from NAACP.
Oh, yeah.
She was the leader.
Well, was she a journalist also for a newspaper or something?
Oh, you don't know?
OK. We don't know that.
But they were intent on seeing that schools were integrated.
The kids could make a difference.
They were satisfied with where they were.
How were those nine kids selected?
Do you remember?
I don't know that.
You don't know?
I'm sure they had to volunteer because they knew there was going to be some problems.
Did you ever meet those nine children?
Never did.
So, but you know that they, I mean, just from general, I mean, the general feeling that no one would want to be placed in that situation, but did you ever hear...
I don't think they wanted to.
But did you ever hear any stories about how they felt, if they were scared or proud to be the ones to make the difference?
I think at that time, papers, radio and television interviewed them and...
that they were concerned and afraid that they would be hurt.
Had to be because even after the federal government sent in troops and stayed there for the rest, they stayed there the entire term.
They stayed there through June, May of 1958.
The troops then?
The federal troops stayed that long.
They were guarded in the classrooms, and they were guarded when they left the school.
How were they received by the white students and the faculty?
Was that all a farce because of the guards, or were they just not well received?
Students didn't receive, didn't welcome the law.
Most of them didn't.
A handful did.
The faculty mixed.
Couldn't do much about it.
In the lunchroom and places like that, did they eat separately?
At a separate time or just off in a group by themselves?
Separately.
They did that in order to prevent any trouble.
That's a good idea.
Would you say, then you would definitely say that these students were even more segregated within the white school than they were outside?
When we were talking about Hortzman High School, what kind of, did they have a mixed faculty or was it all black?
All black.
All black administration and everything?
Everything.
Okay.
What other individuals do you think played a big part in the,
for or against the desegregation movement.
We mentioned Daisy Bates and Virgil Bloom.
Blossom.
Blossom.
You mean locally or?
Well, either.
You mentioned Martin Luther King.
I think the...

I think that the, on the federal government level, between Richard Nixon and William Rogers, his name, he was attorney general, Bill Rogers at that particular time, they, they expressly felt that the Supreme Court ruling was the law of the land, which was questionable that it was the law of the land, and that they were
It was their intent to see that, regardless of what took them, and do it, that it was going to be enforced, which was a great mistake, a great mistake.
How do you think they should have gone about this whole situation?
How do you think it would have been better or easier?
Let the individual school boards across the United States take care of their own plan, and we wouldn't have had any problem at all.
How long do you think it would have taken for the, especially the southern schools, to be integrated if they had gone at their own pace or own speed?
Faster than it took.
than it is what it has to last 25 years, 30 years.
Because they feel like it's something they have to do.
Because any time you're forced to do anything, there's going to be resentment.
And this was forced down the throats of the people across the country, north, south, east, and west.
The North wasn't that different from the South as far as when it came to forced integration.
But they try to make themselves seem better.
People in the North were opposed to it more than the people in the South.
The only reason the South got the attention because that's where, at that time, a great percentage of the black people lived.
There weren't that many percentage-wise in the North and the East and the West, but they were bitterly opposed to it and it took them longer to achieve what degree of integration we have today.
You said that the Guard stayed until May of 1958?
No, no, no.
The National Guard only stayed about a week or so until the Federal Troops moved in.
Okay, but the Federal Troops stayed?
The Federal Troops stayed when Eisenhower ordered Federal Troops in, and I can't remember how many there were, but they stayed until...
School term was out in May.
By the following year.
And is that when the school was shut down that next term?
There was no school at all for two years.
There was no high school at all.
None.
Every high school was closed.
In Little Rock or in Arkansas?
In Little Rock.
Because of the problem.
How did the faculty and the students feel about the guards?
Did they resent that or did they take that resentment that they had for the guards if there was any out on the black students because they were the whole reason that they were there?

Well, I didn't actually talk to faculty members, but I'm certain that they did not agree with either the state or the federal government getting involved in the school administration properly, because that's strictly a local responsibility.
The Constitution of the state of Arkansas and every other state in the union provides specifically for how schools are administered.
that a local school board, elected by the public, has full responsibility.
And the state has no responsibility, and the federal government has no responsibility.
His father saw an opportunity to grab hold of something that was highly, highly emotional at the time, and used it to its fullest extent, perpetuated himself an officer for the next eight years.
That was his only purpose.
Only purpose.
I can't believe that.
Did people support Faubus's actions, the state in general, the community?
Those who didn't support him kept quiet because it was highly controversial, highly controversial.
If you publicly pick a position, which a lot of us did, who because of the position in public life had to, then we became controversial.
And you were either...
considered to be a pretty good fella or you were a pretty bad fella.
And it was decided a lot by that.
Absolutely.
Was it totally by that?
Absolutely.
I had friends and even family members that wouldn't speak to me for two or three years because of that.
They wouldn't speak to you because they felt differently or because they were afraid to speak out in favor of you?
Both.
Both?
Both.
How was your family treated during this time?
I read an article about a cross being burned in your front yard, and I know that your son went to high school there.
Persecuted.
Persecuted.
Was it rough?
Real rough?
Tense?
Not really.
Not really?
Not really when you consider the reason for it.
People did things they wouldn't have done otherwise.
But people in your own church, in your own circle of friends, didn't associate with you.
They were...
I think they were really afraid that they would be drawn into something that was not their business.
I was concerned about it, but not to any great degree.
Did they not speak to you even to the extent of saying hi on the streets?
No, not even?
No, no.
Some family members.
It took a long time to get over it.
I can imagine.
Brent's dad was a senior in high school.
What kind of treatment did he receive?
Well, he didn't know it.
We didn't tell him, but he was guarded everywhere he went.
Undercover?
Oh, yeah.
He was guarded everywhere he went from the time he left the house until the time he got back until school was up the following year.
Then he went to the University of Arkansas the following fall.
Did he receive any flak there from the students, or he was just another student then?
So how long after your term did you stay in Little Rock?
Or did you leave because of this?
No, no, no, no.
I had decided that, well, it became controversial, obviously.
I decided to run for governor and prepared to file.
I realized that because of the position I had taken in this matter right or wrong, that the chance of being elected was practically nil.
And so I decided against filing for nomination or election.
I had been thinking some time about moving our real estate business to a larger community.
And I think probably what happened probably expedited it to some extent because we did business statewide.
I couldn't discuss business if we were talking about politics.
How large was Little Rock at this time?
Little Rock was about, at that time, was about 125,000, 135,000 people.
But I felt at that particular time that I had a, because I was in the office at the time, I had a moral responsibility.
I had a Christian responsibility and a legal responsibility, constitutional responsibility.
And I did what I did because I felt that it was right that they were human beings, not animals, regardless of color.
I felt that the Christian...
The true Christian would have done what I did, regardless of consequences.
And the Constitutional State of Arkansas, and all other states, says that, by law, that the chief executive of any city, any city, has two primary responsibilities.
That is to protect the lives of people and protect property.
I had no choice.
I had no choice.
And I knew when I did it that I had to pay a price, and my family had to pay a price.
But I did the same thing a little bit.
And I didn't necessarily agree.

In fact, I think the greatest, one of the greatest tragedies in the United States in the history of this country was when the Supreme Court made the decision to do away with separate pedigree besides education.
I'll always be.
You believe it should have remained separate but equal?
To this day, I believe.
Because of the controversy?
No, because I think it's the right thing to do.
You can't force people.
You can't force people to do something they don't want to do.
You can't force people to associate if they don't want to.
You can't do it.
And we forced, when they made that decision, and they were forcing people, black and white, all colors,
They were forcing people to associate, and you can't do it.
I think you have a choice.
I think you should have a choice to choose who you want to be your friend and who you want to be with.
You can't legislate by law who your friends are going to be.
And that's exactly what it's all about.
And to this day, to this day, they're doing it.
Busing, for example, is the greatest, most expensive...
thing this country has to do.
When you see kids that live in a block or two of a school and have to get on a bus and ride 25 or 30 miles to go to some school, they don't want to, you know.
Again, you're taking the children of this country and you're forcing them to do something that they don't want to do.
That's not right.
It wasn't right then, it's not right today.
When we get enough men and women with enough backbone to go to Washington, D.C. and change it, you know, then this country will...
and take a step forward and straighten itself out.
And we're in a heck of a mess today on so-called civil rights.
You mean change busing or change the whole separate but equal?
That's just one thing.
That's just one thing.
I think we've already pressed the point now that they're not going to, that we'll always have, we'll always have, in my opinion now, some type of integrated education.
By choice or by?
Well.
It's been 30 years.
I don't think we can go backwards.
But if we could, if we could legally, and I thought that there was enough vote in the Senate and House two years ago that it was going to happen.
But if we could do it with a bunch of children in distant schools and require, make it where...
They go to schools in their community, you know, that we would go a long ways toward getting over the bitterness that we have.
And it's there today.
It's there and it's going to remain there.

Do you feel like the bitterness has recited some that the kids my age, like 20 and younger, are less, I mean much less, a significant amount less bitter than the kids that were in high school when you were mayor?
I don't think so.
You don't think so?
You don't think that there's that much difference between now and then?
I know people today that...
Their children happen to get on buses and ride 10, 15, 20 miles away to school.
And not only do the kids resent it, but the parents resent it very much.
And if they're in a position financially, many, many, many of them are sending their kids to private schools for that reason.
So when people talk about desegregation, integration, in the past tense of something that's been accomplished, you would disagree with that?
Oh, yes.
Most definitely.
Has not been accomplished.
And in my opinion, never will be accomplished, 100%.
So, okay.
Because you're forcing people to do something they don't want to do.
I agree with you.
Do you have anything else that we left out?
Anything about your views?
Well, my views really...
haven't changed in 30 odd years.
I've never said anything publicly, as I told you before.
I went for every year for 15 or 20 years.
When September rolled around, people all over the country, media of various types, would try to run me down.
and seek an interview and get public statements, and I refused to do it.
And still would.
And still would.
I know when I think the 25th anniversary occurred here two or three years ago.
I had, out of New York and California, major television personnel trying to come to Houston and interview me.
And see how your views have changed, if at all?
I haven't said anything publicly, and I've moved to a different district.
After you left Arkansas, did you move to Houston?
Yes.
And set up your business there.
And then did you live out here at Madisonville for a while?
I mean, y'all had a house over that.
We have a ranch up here, a horse ranch, and we released the place in January of 82.
And the intent was to build a house here and
to live here and still have my business operation in Houston.
I had an accident and it became impossible.
But I will eventually do so.
Move back to Madisonville?
Do you have anything else?
Did I forget anything?
Do you have anything to say about the people or the organizations?
Anything that we...
Maybe we didn't elaborate on enough.
The organizations, even the white citizens' councils, did they, and the Ku Klux Klan?
Well, of course, the Ku Klux Klan has been, they've been all based on day one, you know.
They were such a radical group that they should have never existed.
The NAACP, not quite as bad, but to some extent so biased that their real purpose for formation and even Martin Luther King, the same kind of a situation, you know, the same kind of a situation.

I think the very fact that he's eulogized as such a national hero today is because he got involved in the stuff that he did and became an ineffector, inciting people to do things that at that particular time were not acceptable, trying to rush things too fast.
Do you feel like the black people had had enough?
I mean, had it up to where they couldn't stand anymore, and that's why they tried to rush things through?
They just wanted everything at once?
Or do you just feel like they...
I know there's only a handful of people, percentage-wise, in any given cause that will...

become involved to the extent that they give their organization or their particular race a bad name, whether it's civil rights, whether it's organized labor, or this, this, or that, or so forth and so on.
There's only a handful of people that are troublemakers.
By and large, a great majority of people are reasonable and sensible, and they won't get out in front
I think that applies to the Key question plan, the NAACP, and so forth.
Okay.
You can't think of anything else, can you?
No.
Thank you.
You're welcome.
